<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 418, 390, 435]]<|/det|>
READ THESE INSTRUCTIONS FIRST  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 448, 787, 464]]<|/det|>
Write your Centre number, candidate number and name in the spaces at the top of this page.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 464, 325, 479]]<|/det|>
Write in dark blue or black pen.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 479, 504, 495]]<|/det|>
You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 495, 504, 510]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 510, 380, 525]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 540, 285, 555]]<|/det|>
Answer all the questions.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 555, 910, 586]]<|/det|>
Give non- exact numerical answers correct to 3 significant figures, or 1 decimal place in the case of angles in degrees, unless a different level of accuracy is specified in the question.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 586, 593, 601]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 601, 606, 616]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 630, 608, 646]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 646, 757, 661]]<|/det|>
The number of marks is given in brackets [] at the end of each question or part question.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 661, 440, 676]]<|/det|>
The total number of marks for this paper is 50.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 96, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 73, 415, 92]]<|/det|>
Twelve values of \(x\) are shown below.

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[277, 98, 761, 133]]<|/det|>
\[1761.6 \qquad 1758.5 \qquad 1762.3 \qquad 1761.4 \qquad 1759.4 \qquad 1759.1\]

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[277, 112, 761, 133]]<|/det|>
\[1762.5 \qquad 1761.9 \qquad 1762.4 \qquad 1761.9 \qquad 1762.8 \qquad 1761.0\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 144, 920, 163]]<|/det|>
Find the mean and standard deviation of \((x - 1760)\). Hence find the mean and standard deviation of \(x\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[888, 161, 920, 179]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 73, 92, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 73, 920, 108]]<|/det|>
A bag contains 10 pink balloons, 9 yellow balloons, 12 green balloons and 9 white balloons. 7 balloons are selected at random without replacement. Find the probability that exactly 3 of them are green.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 103, 920, 121]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 74, 92, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 920, 123]]<|/det|>
It is found that \(10\%\) of the population enjoy watching Historical Drama on television. Use an appropriate approximation to find the probability that, out of 160 people chosen randomly, more than 17 people enjoy watching Historical Drama on television.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 103, 920, 121]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 74, 94, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>5</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[128, 74, 156, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 73, 920, 108]]<|/det|>
A plate of cakes holds 12 different cakes. Find the number of ways these cakes can be shared between Alex and James if each receives an odd number of cakes.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 87, 920, 106]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 594, 185, 612]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 592, 920, 643]]<|/det|>

<label>6</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 73, 920, 123]]<|/det|>
Pack \(A\) consists of ten cards numbered 0, 0, 1, 1, 1, 1, 1, 3, 3, 3. Pack \(B\) consists of six cards numbered 0, 0, 2, 2, 2, 2. One card is chosen at random from each pack. The random variable \(X\) is defined as the sum of the two numbers on the cards.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[126, 134, 156, 153]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 133, 363, 153]]<|/det|>
Show that \(\mathrm{P}(X = 2) = \frac{2}{15}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 135, 920, 153]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 345, 154, 364]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 345, 542, 364]]<|/det|>
Draw up the probability distribution table for \(X\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 346, 920, 364]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 96, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>7</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 146, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 73, 920, 122]]<|/det|>
The lengths, in centimetres, of middle fingers of women in Raneland have a normal distribution with mean \(\mu\) and standard deviation \(\sigma\). It is found that \(25\%\) of these women have fingers longer than \(8.8 \text{cm}\) and \(17.5\%\) have fingers shorter than \(7.7 \text{cm}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[168, 128, 198, 147]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[201, 128, 413, 147]]<|/det|>
Find the values of \(\mu\) and \(\sigma\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 128, 920, 147]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 599, 920, 650]]<|/det|>
The lengths, in centimetres, of middle fingers of women in Snoland have a normal distribution with mean 7.9 and standard deviation 0.44. A random sample of 5 women from Snoland is chosen.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 657, 193, 675]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[198, 656, 920, 675]]<|/det|>
Find the probability that exactly 3 of these women have middle fingers shorter than \(8.2 \text{cm}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 672, 920, 691]]<|/det|>
